title: אֶל מִי מִגּוֹאֲלֵי | El Mi Migoalei (To whom among the redeemers), a rehuṭah piyyuṭ for Yom Kippur by Avraham ben-Shmuel (Abulafia) translated by Avi Solomon
author: Avi Solomon (translation)

coauthors.name: Avi Solomon (translation)
coauthors.bio: Avi Solomon, a Bene Israel Jew from India, lives in Israel and translates Abraham Abulafia's Ḳabbalah, and related works, into English from Hebrew.

coauthors.name: Avraham ben Shmuel Abulafia
coauthors.bio: Avraham ben Shmuel Abulafia (Hebrew: אברהם בן שמואל אבולעפיה) (1240-after 1291), born in Zaragoza, Spain, was the founder of the "Prophetic" school of Ḳabbalah. Early in life he was taken by his parents to Tudela, Navarre, where his aged father, Samuel Abulafia, instructed him in Torah and Talmud. In 1258, when Abulafia was eighteen years old, his father died, and Abulafia began a life of ceaseless wandering shortly thereafter. His first journey, in 1260, was to Erets Yisrael, where he intended to begin a search for the legendary Sambatyon and the Ten Lost Tribes. He got no further than 'Akko (Acre), however, because of the desolation and lawlessness stemming from the chaos following the recent Crusade. The battle that year between the Mongol Empire and Mamluk Sultanate forced his return to Europe via Greece. He had determined to go to Rome but stopped short in Capua, where during the early 1260s, he devoted himself to the study of philosophy and The Guide for the Perplexed of Maimonides under the tutelage of a philosopher and physician named Hillel—probably the well-known Hillel ben Samuel of Verona. On his return to Spain he became subject to visions, and, at the age of thirty-one, in Barcelona, began to study a particular kind of Ḳabbalah whose most important representative was Barukh Togarmi, and received a revelation with messianic overtones. He soon left for Castile, where he disseminated his prophetic Kabbalah among figures like Rabbi Moses of Burgos and his most important disciple, Joseph ben Abraham Gikatilla. Some time around 1275; he taught The Guide for the Perplexed and his Kabbalah in a few cities in Greece. He wrote the first of his prophetic books, Sefer haYashar, in Patras in 1279. That same year, he made his way through Trani back to Capua. He went to Rome in 1280 in order to convert Pope Nicholas III to Judaism on the day before Rosh Hashanah. The Pope was in Soriano when he heard of it, and he issued orders to "burn the fanatic" as soon as he reached that place. The stake was erected in preparation close to the inner gate; but Abulafia set out for Soriano all the same and reached there August 22. While passing through the outer gate, he heard that the Pope had died from an apoplectic stroke during the preceding night. He returned to Rome, where he was thrown into prison by the Order of Friars Minor but was liberated after four weeks' detention. He remained active in Messina for a decade (1281–1291), presenting himself as a "prophet", "messiah" and "son of God". He had several students there as well as some in Palermo. The local Jewish congregation in Palermo condemned Abulafia's conduct, and around 1285 addressed the issue to Shlomo ben Aderet of Barcelona, who subsequently wrote a letter against Abulafia. Under distressing conditions compiled his Sefer haOt on the little island of Comino, near Malta, between 1285 and 1288. In 1291 he wrote his last, and perhaps his most intelligible work, the meditation manual Imrei Shefer; after this, all trace of him is lost.

content:
This liturgical poem is read by Sefardic congregations around the globe on the holy day of Yom Kippur. The poem’s acrostic reads Abraham ben Samuel. [Although the name Abulafia is not indicated in the acrostic,] Samuel was Avraham Abulafia’s father’s name and the same technique and name is used in the chapter headings of Light of the Intellect. Intriguing!
Source (Hebrew) Translation (English)
אֶל מִי מִגּוֹאֲלֵי דָם אֶצְעַק
וְיָדַי שָׁפְכוּ דָמִים
To whom among the reD-eeMers[1] The letters D and M here are capitalized, an allusion to דם (Hebrew: DaM). I could have translated “To whom among those bloodied with blood” but chose to play with גואל.  of blood can I cry out to,
when my own hands have shed blood?
בָּחַנְתִּי לִבּוֹת מְשַׂנְאִים
וְאֵין שׂוֹנֵא אוֹתִי כִּלְבָבִי
Having examined hatred in hearts,
no heart despises me as my own.
רָבוּ פִּצְעֵי אוֹיְבִים וּמַכּוֹתָם
וְאֵין מוּכֵּה וּפָצוּעַ כְּנַפְשִׁי
Blows and wounds by my enemies multiply,
but there is no striker and wounder as my own soul.
הִדִּיחוּנִי מַשְׁחִיתִים לְחַבֵּל
וְאֵין מַסִּית וּמַדִּיחַ כְּעֵינַי
The corrupt have ensnared me into sabotage,
but there is no slanderer and ensnarer as my own eyes.
מִגַּחַל אֶל גַּחַל הִתְהַלַּכְתִּי
וְלֹא שְֹרָפַתְנִי אֵשׁ כְּחוֹם תַּאֲוָתִי
I have stepped from ember to ember,
but no fire has torched me as the heat of my own lust.
בְּפַחִים נִלְכַּדְתִּי וּמְצוֹדוֹת
וְלֹא לְכָדַנִי מוֹקֵשׁ כִּלְשׁוֹנִי
I have been trapped in pits and by nets,
but no mine has caught me as my own tongue.
נְשָׁכוּנִי נָחָשׁ וְעַקְרָב
וְאֵין נוֹשֵׁךְ בְּשָׂרִי כְּשִׁינַּי
Snake and scorpion have stung me,
but no one bites my flesh like my own teeth.
שׁוֹדְדִים עַל קַל רְדָפוּנִי
וְאֵין רוֹדֵף אוֹתִי כְּרַגְלַי
Robbers have pursued me on horses,
but I have no pursuer like my own two feet.
מַכְאוֹבַי אִמְּצוּ מִמֶּנִּי
וְאֵין מַכְאוֹבִי כְּמִרְיִי
My tribulations have overwhelmed me,
but there is no pain to match my own melancholy.
וִיכַבְּדוּ מַדְוֵי לְבָבִי
וַעֲוֺנַי יוֹתֵר מִכּוּלָּם
Heavy are the sorrows of my heart,
but my sin overwhelms them.
אֶל מִי אֶצְעַק וְאֶל מִי
וּמַחֲרִיבַי מִמֶּנִּי יֵצֵאוּ
To whom can I cry out to, to whom?
for my destroyers emerge from myself.
לֹא מָצָאתִי לִי טוֹב
כִּי אִם לָבוֹא בְּסֵתֶר רַחֲמֶיךָ
I have found no good
except to find refuge in the cave of your mercy.
רַחֲמֶיךָ הַפְלֵא עַל לֵב הַנִּשְׁבָּר
אֵל מֶלֶךְ יוֹשֵב עַל כִּסֵּא רַחֲמִים
Your compassion cures the broken heart,
O Lord, my King, reposed on the throne of mercy!

This is “El Mi Migoalei,” a rehuṭah piyyut for Yom Kippur by Avraham ben Shmuel, as indicated by the acrostic signature (likely the same person as Avraham Abulafia.) Our transcription of the text follows that found in National Library of Russia, Ms. EVR II A 913. The vocalization is based on the niqqud published by Ḥaim Sherman (transcribed by Project Ben Yehuda), which contains some variation in wording not found in our manuscript. Our niqqud conforms to the wording found in the manuscript used for our transcription (not Sherman’s).

This translation of “El Mi Migoalei” was made by Avi Solomon and first published via his patreon page, on 31 October 2019. The poem was introduced ten months prior, along with page images of the piyyut, in Avi’s post, “A poem by Abraham Abulafia in the Siddur?” on 16 January 2019.

While the attribution to Abulafia cannot be known with absolute certainty, the play of words beginning with אל, לא, and אין (‘to whom,’ ‘no,’ and ‘not’), ultimately inverted in the final line to אל (‘Deity’), strikes me as very Abulafian at a time when ḳabbalists were seeking innovation with the mystical via negativa tradition inherited via Maimonides. –Aharon Varady
